div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,143] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are intended to leave Port Baid on or about the following dates:
Port-Said to London Via Brindisi
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails. Combined steamer and sleeping care fair from Port-Said to london via Brindisi or via Marseiles.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Suez about March 10
R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about March 24.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Port Said about March 18
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about March 27th
N.B.- Homward steamers are sometimes before shels advertised daies,
Passengers landed and embarked at Ismailia, Quearantine Regulations permitting, free of all expenses.
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,966 tons, leaves about March 16.
S.S. Chershore 5,708 tons, leaves about March 30.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about March 6.
S.S. Shropshire 5,220 tons leaves about March 20.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Fitted with Refridgerators, Electric Light, Electric fans, and all recent improvements.
Experienced Stweardesse and Surgeons carried - Agents in Cairo, Messre Thod, Cook & Son.
For all particuars apply to W. Stapledon & Son, Port-Said & Port-Tawfik (Suez)
Note. – The outward Bibby willhenceforth leave suex one day later than before.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.

S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

MANUFACTURERS OF THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT Centrifugal Pumping Machinery In the world, suitable fcr all purposes, including RECLAMATION, DRAINAGE, IRRIGATION, SEWAGE WORKS, GRAVING & FLOATING DOCKS, MINES, & ALL MANUFACTURING PURPOSES.
These Pumps can be driven by Steam, Gas, Oil, Water, Electricity, or other power, for Lifts of from 1 ft. to 500ft., and from 5 to 500,000 Gallons a Minute. Makers of the Mex Pumps.
Results Guaranteed.
Over 50 Years' Practical Experience.
All kinds of Pumping and Irrigation Machinery specially designed to meet Egyptian requirements.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels.
div.p: Catarnot Hotel, Assouan.

Thos most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the additoon of 65 rooms and accomodates 360 gruests. Grand dining hall, lift, tennis courts and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billiard room and bar., Electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel Assouan. - Under the same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accomodates 50 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beautiful Terrance overlooking river. Electric light throughout.

div.head: Grand Hotel Khartoum
div.p: Standing in a magnificent position in its own grounds on the high banks of the blue nile
Elegantly Furnished; every comfort and convenience; through connection with London ; perfect climate ; lovely gardens ; excellent cuisine. - Wire Manager, Hotel, Khartoum.

div.head: The Austrian Travel and Information Bureau
div.p: (Under the DIrection of the I. R. Austrian - Railway Ministry.)
86, Piccadilly, London, W.
The Most delightful and health-giving resorts for Anglo-Egyptian Officials are the Alpine districts of Austria which can be reached in a few hours from Trieste.
Excellent Hotels ( to suit every pocket ) abound situated in high latitudes of great recuperative power specially recommended by doctors for those who have spent a considerable time in hot climate.
Various high Anglo-Egyptian Officials have already engageed villas, rooms at hotels, etc., for the ensuing vacation season.
Shootings and FIshings (at very low prices) can be arragned through the Bureau, also Castles and Villas can be let of sold.
The fullest information as to cost of tours travelling and on every point will be sent by the bureau on receipt of request.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: THroughout the day the wind blew rather fresh from the westward with a rough sea and clear air, but towards sunset it died away to a flat calm and again at 3 a.m. freshened up from the S. S. W. Lightly with a slight sea; clear but damp Barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

div.head: THE S.P.C.A. in EGYTPT
div.p: We should like to call the attention both of our regular readers and of the visitors staying in Egypt, whose numbers are greater now than they have ever been, to the tenth annual report of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Mr. Horaoe Rumbold, the honorary secretary and treasurer of the society, in his most interesting report, which is accompanied by very full statements of aooounts and of the financial position of the branches established at Zagazig, Mansourah, Tantah, Assiout, Luxor, and Assouan, notes that both the balance and the receipts from subscriptions and donations have diminished during the past year. The falling off in subscriptions he ascribes to the foot that many former subscribers have left Egypt, while their places have remained unfilled. The decrease in the donations indicates either indifference to the aims of the society, or a oomplete misunderstanding of its financial position. Ignorance cannot well be pleaded : there is not a single large hotel at Cairo, or Helouan where the notices of the 8-P.C.A. do not occupy prominent positions, and it is impossible to imagine for a moment that the average tourist has suddenly become hardened to the possibility of animal suffering. There remains the other alternative: that one visitors mis understand the financial situation of the society, and this we believe to be the cause of the decreased support which Mr. { Rumbled notes. In this the last paragraph of the report deserves quotation in ; fulfill “The society has now completed 10 years’ work, during which it may fairly claim to have | brought about a complete change in the Condition of animals in and around Cairo. Visitors and residents, who have known Cairo before S.P.C.A. existed, are unanimous in bearing wi ness to the revolution brought about through the agency. The sum recovered in the course the year from owners of animals treats in the infirmary must inevitably constitute the largest proportion of the income of the society. Experience has shown, however, this the receipts under this head can never equate the expenditure, and that the society will • ways be dependent, to & certain extent, c outside contributions. Residents in Egypt fully do their duty in supporting the society The same cannot be said of the thousands will visit Egypt every winter. The contribution of visitors during 1904 scarcely reached L.E.2 out of a total income of over L.K.3,500. J no year have they exceed L.K.100. £ platonic sympathy with the and objects of the society are readily forth coming, but do not assume a concrete or practical shape” The italics are ours, for to passage deserves to be emphasised : it is eat to assume an interested sympathetic air but unfortunately this simulated interest has a wi of departing with those who have aroused i Quite number of otherwise excellent people respond to an appeal to their sympathy adult generosity with the regularity of one of tho pleasing machines, once so popular in British seaside resorts, into while penny was insert! and a puppet willingly danced or played put the simulacrum of a musical instrument, ai with about the same practical result. We confess to a fear that exhortations ai appeals will prove vain against such meter cal temperaments, but there must be urban of whiter visitors whose intellects are as precept cal as their instincts are generous, and who Da to support the S.P.C.A. as it( deserves owing! a misapprehension of its financial position. realise as well as they do that the society to deal with Cairo thoroughly and effectively, but they do not realise that, unless • the society to mark time, perhaps for years, then help needed to enable it to extend its operation in the provinces. A society that confirm its work for ever to the Capital you deserve to be compared to a police thi enforced peace and order in London, Brig ton, Birmingham, and Manchester and, oo tentedly supine, permitted outlaws to reassei bio in Sherwood Forest and highwayman to haunt the Portsmouth road. It is ti wish of the committee and members of to S.P.C.A. to give to their operations a wid scope, and sooner or later to establish enter at all the principal towns in Egypt, from who the treatment of animals, not only in the towns, but in the surrounding villages, can I watched, and infraction* of the laws relating cruelty to animals noted and brought before the responsible authorities. Anyone who 1 the fellaheen of Egypt understands that all their good points, they are curiously less of animal suffering, and indict a amount of unnecessary pain on the beasts of they possess and, at times, on the wild tares that Call into their hands. We do wish to give any colour to the that the Moslem is cruel to beasts hi Moslem, for the enlightened Mob holds strong views as to his duty town animals, and will bite passages from Koran in favor of humanity. But ran in Christian and in ^lost cities is usually accompanied by a cruelty towards animal suffering, the consequence of which differ in no way from those active cruelty, and the fellah is admitted ignorant and callous. We therefore vent to appeal to our visitors to remember the there are other places in Egypt besides Cair Luxor, and Assouan, and that while to S.P.C.A. has done great things in a limits area and with limited resources, it needs help to enable it to continue and to extend its work. No amount of good wishes balances a donation, however small.

div.head: BATTLE STILL RAGING.
div.p: RUSSIANS IN FULL RETREAT.
Mukdin’s Fall Imminent
BLOODiEST BATTLE OF WAR.
AppaL1NG LOSSES.
^. Tokio, March 8.

Marshal Oyama reporta that a. division ot the enemy with 70 guns was repulsed at Taahicliinu, ei^lit mi his to the north-west ui Mukden. * Inc battle is proceeding favorably lor us some 10 miles to the south-east, and the same distance -to the south oi Fu&hau despite the stubborn resistance of the enemy/' The report doea uot. indicate substantial progress anywhere. (Hauler.)
Lon non, March 8.

Reuter s Agency learns trorn Mukden that on the bth iust., the sixth day of the battle, the ligating on the west llank raged uuceas* gly irom (lawn till dusk. The Japanese were < huuiy established at Machiapu, and they Iso pushed their line iurther north, 'xussian losses already exceed those at . and it is estimated that the Jupa- •les are greater.
S mat., the Japanese continued , jovement. One division extend- ec ection of Tiding. '1 he firing ol its

urti shifted north almost to the Sm-Miu- Ting oad, lioin whence a number of Japanese w blinded were biougbt in. Fighting was .also ueard lur away to the north. The attack on tue front was meanwhile* maintained, 'ihu Japanese are re-advanciug on the extreme east, i he Russians are still holding the centre, but nu the south-west are retiring on their second positions.(Hauler, j
Tokio, March 8. The Russians evacuated the line east of the Ska Ho during the night. {Havas.,
St. Pltehsburo, March 8.
General Kuropatkin telegraphs on the 7th inst. that the enemy’s attacks have been repulsed in the centre and left dank. (Havas.j
Tokio* March 8.
The Japaueso captured Machuntan in the morning. (Havas, j
Mukden, March 8.
The battlo continues to rage and is exhausting both sides. The dual issue is still hauging in the balance. (Hauler./
London, March 8.

Reuter’s correspondent with General Kuroki cabling on Wednesday states that the Russians, profiting by the darkness, evacuated ail the positions along the Sba-Ho. They are now in full retreat. They fired huge quantities ol supplies. The Japanese are pressing them haid and the fall of Mukden is imminent.

Reuter’s corre.-poudent with General Oku says that, owing to the tlatuess of the Cuuutry, the battle on the west is entirely conducted by telephone. The Russians latterly have been demoralised by tbe irresistible rushes of the Japanese. It is believed that some Russian regiments are on the vergo of mutiny.
The Jap&i.ese are now bridging the Hun-Ho.
( Hauler.
St. Petersburg, March 9.
A Russian telegram from Mukden says that yesterday at 10.0 iu the morning the heavy caunDnading on tbe northwest was shaking tbe houses of the town.
Au engagement was proceeding near the Imperial tombs. (Heutar.j
Tokio, March 9.
General Kuropatkin has evidently been badly .eaten in the most bloody battle of the war.'
(Otficial). The Russiaus began retreating yesterday morning. t All the Japanese armies iro vigorously pursuing them. (Heutar.)
London, March 9.

The “times” learns from St. Petersburg that ieneral Kuropatkin reported yesterday tliat ke Japanese had massed an enormous force o the north-west of Mukden,thus necessitating n immediate retreat The Russian losses uring the first ten days of the battle are offi- ially given as being nearly 33,000, including 30 officers. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND RUSSIAN LOAN
div.p: London, March 8. The “Times” says that the French finan- rs intimated to Russia tliat the new loan i«t not exceed £20,000,000 instead of 2,000,000, and, furthermore, that this will the last loan to be raised in Paris for some rs. (Reuter.)

div.head: BRITISH COLLIERS SEIZED.
div.p: Tokio, March 8. Phe British colliers “Venus” and “Aphrodite,” bound for Vladivostok, have been seised oy the Japanese t (Reuter.)

div.head: Russian Revolt
div.p: Movement Gaining Strength
St. Petersburg, March 8. 'lhe movement of revolt in the country districts of Russia is gaining strength. Bauds of armed peasants are marching through the, villages damaging property. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, March 9. The men ot tbe Baltic Naval dockyard hore have struck work, owing to the arrest of their elected representatives. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: RETURNS TO DJIBOUTI.
, Paris, March 8. The “Temps” learns from Antananarivo that the entjre Russian Fleet left Madagascar for Djibouti. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE CHARCOT EXPEDITION.
div.p: Buenos Ayres, March 9.- The Charcot expedition has returned safely.
(Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Red Sea Lighthouses.—We have to acknowledge the receipt of a parcel of books for the Red Sea lighthouse keepers from Sheehan Bay.
The S.S. “Cairo.”— The enquiry at the Italian Consulate has not yet closed. The salvage steamer “Hermes” was engaged on the wreck this morning.
Agricultural Congress. — The Egyptian Government will most probably be represented at the furthcoming Agricultural Congress at Rome by Boghos Paoha JNubar.
Savoy Ball.—The fancy-dress ball and bal puudre will lake place at the Savoy Hotel ou lueaday next, 14tb inst. Season tickets lor the Savoy small dances allow holders to attend the bail. _

Investments.—Application has been macle to the London Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day iu and to grant a quotation to: Egyptian Investment and Iyrncy, 200,000 abates ol £1 each, 5s. paid.

Suez Canal.—25 vessels passed through the Cuual on the 4 th and 5th inst. 15 ot these were British, 3 German, 2 Austrian, 2 French, 3 Hutch. The receipts lor the two days were irs. 620,537.72, making a total lrom 1st inst. of irs. 1,649,612.31.

Provincial Councils. — The Provincial Councils of tlie Fayoum, Behera and Menoufieh provinces have been summoned by Khedivial Decree to meet on Thursday next, the I6lh inst,, iu order to elect delegates lor the Legislative Council. The elections will be helu at the Moudirieh towns.

Murderess Sentenced.— The now Assize court at Cairo has passed sentence ol haru labour for life ou the native woman who was iound guilty of having thrown the young daughter ot Mustapba Izzet, who was in her charge, into a well, so as to obtain possession ui the child’s gold earrings.

Army of Ucccfation.—The 4th Mountain Battery, Royal Garrison Artillery, will leave Cairo (Abbaasieh> by special train on Saturday at 6.10 p.m. for Port-Said, where they wilt arrive at 1.5 a.m. ou Sundi ,. They will, il necessary remain in the tram till 8 am. and atterwards embark ou the transport “Soudan” for passage home.

Parturient Montes.—After the elaborate exposition of the great principles involved in the institution of the new Assize Courts, delivered with the souorous accent and impressive Arabic which is at the command ol the Vice-President of the Native Court ol Appeal, tbe first case that came ou for hearing dealt solely with the theft of a saucepan 1

Cairo’s New Opera House.—The Ministry of Public Works is atpreseut engaged in the investigation and study of the most up-to-date opera bouses in Europe aud America, and ha« specially studied the problem ot how to deal with the risk of fire. But while the designs are well advanced, the question of the site of a new opera-house in Cairo has uot yet been solved. Proposals have been made which the Miuistry has been unable to accept, owing to their commercial character.

div.head: Savoy Hotel, Luxor.
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its psition on the Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronized by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Weissenstein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrai ' Station, Lienx (reached from Venice or Trieste). Bracing air. Good Mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. best June, September. Apply Proprietor.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the west Central position. Under English management.

div.head: THE EGYPTIN PILGRIMAGE
div.p: . RETURN OF SACRED CARPET.

The first batch of Egyptian pilgrims returning from Mecca left Jeddah yesterday by the Khedivial Mail steamer “Assouan,” and the Sacred Carpet with the escort, suite, andpilgrims accompanying, left Jeddah on Tuesday by the same company’s S.S. ‘Rahmanieh,” “Payoum,” and “Negbileh” for Yambo, en route for Medina.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive has arrived at Montazah, and
is proceeding to Mariout.

div.head: RODAH ISLAND.
div.p: The Cairo newspapers have been publishing a number of incorrect statements as to the proposals for the purchase ol 52 feddans on Rodah Islaud by Messrs. Zervudachi & Co. The land in question does not belong to the Wakfs Administration but to the heirs of Aly Pasha Cherif, and the Wakfs Administration has only managed the property provisionally until the heirs come to some agreement. One of the heira has made an “opposition legale” to the sale.

div.head: SHEIKH FADL ESTATE CO.
div.p: Among tbe numerous land companies which are springing up almost daily in Egypt, is the Sheikh Fadl Estate Company. The capital of this company is 8,625,000 franca and is divided into 86,250 shares of 100 francs each. Of these, 21,563 have been subscribed for by M. Maurice M. Cattaui and the remaining 64,687 as follows : M. Fdlix Suar&s, 3,645 ; Mme. Heuriette Su&r&s, 305; Mine. Hll&ne de Menasce, 153 ; M. Gustave Suarta, 1,986 ; M.Andrd Suarta, 1,986 ; Mme. Linda Suarta, 1,986 ; Mile. Laure Suarts, 1,986 ; Mile.'Marie Suarts, 153 ; M. Raphael Suarta, 12,355 ; M. Enrico Nabman, 1,286 ; M. Simon Rolo, 6,610; M. Jacques Kolo, 8,274 ; M. Charles Beyerl^, 9,698 ; M. Joseph A. Cattfiui Bey, 8,324 ; M. Robert S. Rolo, 2,479 ; Mme. Valentine Rolo, 153 ; M. Leon Suares, 1,986 ; M. Marchetto Matatia, 1,322.

The members of the board of administration will be Messrs. Fdlix 8uarts, Raphael Suari^, Ch. Beyerte, Simon R. Rolo, Jacques R. Rolo, Enrico Xahman, M. Cattaui Bey, Joseph A. Cattaui Bey, Robert S. Rolo, Leon Suar&s, aud Marchetto Matatik Tbe Sheikh Fadl estate consists of 8,800 feddaus and 10 kirats.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES, LTD.
div.p: We arc informed that the ordinary shares of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, are being dealt in on the London Stock Exchange at 5a. premium.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: LONDON OPINION.
A London financial correspondent writes :—

The expected movement in Egyptian miuing shares is at hand, or at any rate it seems so. Norlh Niles will probably wait ontil Nile Valleys give a lead, but those in tbe market who regard them with even greater favor than the shares of the older company (from a purely market standpoint) are not entirely without reasons. The issued capital is very small, only about £39,000, and an appreciation in price would probably be more rapid in the case ot the subsidiary than in that of the parent. By band crushing alone £3,000 worth of gold bsB been recovered, and 5,000 feet of development work has been done, Nubias are quiet, and so are the rest of the list, bnt there are various considerations which point to an impending revival of interest in this section.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION.
div.p: The report for 1904 states that the Urn Rus Gold Mines of Egypt (Limited) with a capital of £150,000, of which £50,000 is working capital, was ’ issued to the public on the 6th of February last year, and the purchase consideration of £5,000 cash aud 33,333 fully-paid shares has been paid over to the company. It is expected that regular crush- ings on the Um Rus Mine will commence in the course of a few weeks. Five thousand of the remaining 40,000 unisoued working capital shares were applied for and allotted at the close of the financial year. The company has now ample funds in hand, as the subsidiary companies in which they are largely interested are carrying on the development work, and no expenditure on this account is being incurred by the company. Just after the close of tbe year the Sudan Minos (Limited) was formed to acquire the Sudan Concession, with a capital of £60,000, of which £20,000 is working capital, the company receiving 12,833 shares, fully paid, for the concession.

div.head: PILOTAGE AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Finance Miuistry has altered danse 14 of the Alexandria Pilotage Rules, of the 31st December, 1896. The clause now reads as follows :—

“Si les pilotes se trouvent dans l’imposri- bilitl d’aborder les navires k cause de la grosse mer, ie signal V du Code International sera hiss<$ kbord du remorqueur ou de rembarca- tion des pilotes pour indiqner que l’abordage n’est pas possible. En pared cas, le navire devra franohir la passe sous la direction de ses propres officiers ou res ter en dehors de la passe jusqu’h ce que le temps devienne suffi- samment cal me pour permettro au pilote de monter kbord.
“Ce drapeau sera hissl kbord do bateau* pilote indlpendamment de tout autre signal de oette nature fait k Kom-EFNadoure."

div.head: HGHEZIREEH CASINO BALL.
div.p: A BRILLIANT SPECTACLE.

The fancy-drees ball at the Ghezireh Casino on Tuesday night was a remarkably brilliant and successful entertainment. Residents and visitors came in crowds, some powdered, many in fancy dress, and it was one of those nights when the phrase “nearly everybody seems to be here” was true for once in a way. A list of those who were present would be too long for our space—and perhaps for our readers—besides being impossible to give, and we oonfine ourselves to a description of the costumes that impressed us most, though we cannot pretend to describe the dresses worn by so many fair members of tbe more charming sex, and mtast apologise to all those whom we may leave uomentioned for the lack of taste that drove us to neglect, or the forgetfulness that prevent- ed us from noting, what they wore.

The ball room of the Ghezireh Palace Casino always looks well when lit up and decorated, and never looked better than on Tuesday night, wheu the costumesof the dancers,mostly in excellent taste, and worn with grace, made a wonderful ‘V»up d'ceil.” It would be i possible to piok opt tbe best—comparisons of costumes are the most odious of all,—but we may say that Mr. Geoffrey Milward, in black and orange brown, was one of the finest Morgans or Captains Kidds that we have ever seen. Mrs. Milward, powdered aud in rich brocade, deserves special praise for not waving her hair; result—a costume thoroughly in keeping with the XVillth century and historically accurate. Many others wore their hair in the manner of the XXth century, and the picture, charming in parts, just failed to oonvince as a whole.

Another pirate, and a gigantic and redoubtable figure in three-cornered hat and waving plumes, was Bimbashi Kelly, E.A. Bimbasbi Cummins looked well as a Rapin from Montmartre, and we must not forget Capt. Byrne as a Mousquetaire of the Guard of the Bourbons, and Capt. Jeimings (R. I. Fus.), who impersonated with singular accuracy an Egyptian warrior of the monuments. Miss Rees looked charming as a paysanne. Miss Joseph and Miss Walford were Veroniques : each had treated the part in a different spirit and each succeeded iu giving a charming picture of Messager’s heroine. Miss Pigeon as Queen Winter, adomed with holly and icicles, and Miss Gladys Royle, as a white and stately Dresden shepherdess, were amazingly good., and we must not forget Mr. Young, arrayed as a buck of George IV.’s days. There were groups, too. and the best of these came from the officers of the 2ud Royal Inniskiliing Fusiliers, Mrs. Steward, as “Alice in Wonderland,” leading into the ball room all the heroes of the story, the Mad Hatter, Tweedledum and Tweed led ee, the Red aud White Queens, the White Knight, long spoon for the nasal of his helmet, course the Walrus and the Carpenter, its and Pierrettes swarmed, as did tbe the suits, and Queens of Hearts and Kings ofl^iamouds. There were Dervishes, too, of ferocious aspect, amoug whom Major Delavoye and Capt Bigge doomed large on the limited horizon ol the ball-room. Mr. Forestier- Walker had the happy idea of appearing as a black “La Tosca.” Capt Whiffen was a very desperate-looking desperado, and Capt Tncker a huge aud picturesque stock rider. Mr. Soott- Moncrieff was a dark and diabolical Arab ; will be pardon ns for saying that he evoked memories of coaling at Port Said ? Mr. Peyton aud Mr. Clogstouu were sailor-boys, while Mr. Paxton and Mr. Tod appeared as costers in all the glory of pearlies and wonderfully cat continuations. Dr. Phillips, as a barrister, Mr. Welldon, as a convict, and Mr. Hankey, as a cavalier, all deserve mention. There were Japanese of both sexes, among whom Mrs. Garrett, Mrs. Drummond-Hay, and Miss Hume were charming Geishas. Mrs. Warnock as a Marquise and Mrs. Elliot Smith as Evangeline looked extremely well, and Mrs. Symmors was a most successful Portia. Many ladies bad merely powdered, and powder suited them.- Mrs. Wild and Mrs. Donegan looked very well so, while pictoies served as models to Miss Caution, who made a charming Romney, and to Mrs. Ray, who in powder, ringlets, skirts and picture hat, followed Gainsborough. Mr. Moroorn was an effective Sheikh. Messrs. Hicks and ltobiuson were impressive students of A1 Azhar, while Maj. Donegan and Mr. S. de Bilinaki appeared in hunting pink. There were some splendid Bedouins, Mr. Niabet and Mr. Bennett perhaps most striking of them all, and Miss de Codt was a picturesque aud accurate Dolly Varden. Mr. Blencowe came as a Toreador, as did Capt Carey, who was aocompauied by Miss Carey, who was remarkably good as Cannon, and we must not forget Mohamed Bey—we do not know which of the many Mohamed Beys he is, but hear that he is Prince Halim’s wakeel— who came arrayed as a Pathan notable.

The Hon. Arthur Davey looked extremely well as a Pierrot The Hon. Mrs. Davey was very much admired as “Black and White.” Another very artistic costume was that of Miss Leverich, in black and silver, as “Night” Then there was a Sunflower Girl and many others, the vague memory of whom makes us curse our forgetfulness of the details of their dress.

The dancing was animated. That goes without saying on such occasions. At 1 a.m. a great multitude swarmed to supper and overflowed to side rooms where flash-light photos were taken. After supper came more dancing till 5.15 a.m., when the ball at last ended. The arrangements were as perfect as they always are at Ghezireh. May the Savoy dance on the 14th rival this—it will be very hard to surpass it.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: London, March 3rd it may be safely stated that the source* of information at the disposal of the magnate* of the London Stock Exchange are more far-rr ch- ing and reliable than any other. Even the I eat opinion of the chances of succees of the armies in the field, with all the gathered available news from public and private sources, can be, and no doubt is, secured by those to whom the upshot of events means loss or gain of many millions. When, therefore, a movement of general confidence takes place, and Consols and other securities (whioh,so to speak,“beattime”) and Japanese Stocks show special strength, it is easy to gauge “the fact” that the best informed have made up their minds as to the general course of events. The latest information from Manchuria seems to have fully confirmed these views, and amply justified the discounting of the future that has taken place. There is ofily oue weak spot. Will the French* holders of Kmmi*n stock lose their heads “en masse” in case ot the farther casualties impeding ? T‘ at the fall of Port Arthur, the destructio t oi .he Russian fleet, and the state of practical t t u tion into which Russia has been plunge a by the insensate action oi the Tsar, have been borne by the French investor frith extraordi nary ‘’sang froid,” so much so that the power of obtaining new loans in that oountry seems still unexhausted,give reason to hope that they will bear future troubles without panic. Certainly the conditions of sale, and the advioe from head-centres, will act in that direction. The French are, however, an impulsive people, aud liable to act foolishly when once “on the run.” Should the scare take place, what would be the effect t This has been well thought-out and discussed in high financial circles this week, with the conclusion that, with prices of best securities at their present level, there is not much to fear. The weight ot a heavy drop would fall on Paris, and „at the moment, being in au exceptionally strong monetary position, should be able to bear it. French holders of South African shares would, no doubt, be obliged to realise to some extent, heuce the halting condition of that market,but otherwise the effect on our Stock Exchange would' be mostly sympathetic, and the result of near peace, coming as an offset to Russian disasters, would have a strengthening tendency. The very lall in Russians, if it take place, will make an unanswerable argument for peeoe, for, as Napoleon said, to oommand success in war three things are essential1st, money; 2nd, money; 3rd, money.

Gilt-edged securities still continue to be the leading feature of the stock-markets, and at the time of writing they stand generally at the highest .level touched lor a long time past Money is cheap, and, what is more important, there is strong evidence that, in this section at any rate, there is a revival of public confidence. Thure has been a steady demand for better-class stocks, which has been well sustained dining the past lew weeks. The supply of investment stocks is comparatively limited, and a continuance of buying in this quarter, such as seems more than probable, mast ultimately so raise prices that in a lew months’ time, perhaps ieas,they will teach a level which will yield a very much smaller return, and moreover, leave much less scope for speculation than is the case at present. Then we shall see the further result, viz. the poblio will turn to those markets which offer them most scope, and there will be a consequent return ol activity in speculative stocks. Egyptian properties have fluctuated- considerably this week. Natiou&l Bauks are tbe most active feature, having fallen beluw 26$ early in the week, but steadied again to 27 later. It is only to be expected that the rapid rise in prioe should produce a fairly large amount of profit making, for, good-as this property undoubtedly is, the upward movement has been very rapid, and the return at pieseut is certainly not proportionate, still less high enough to tempt holders to look them up at these prioes. Agricultural Banks are steady at lli- Daira Sanieh shares keep their prioe well at 25}r and are talked higher. Egyptiau Salt and Soda at 2| seem high, but the shares are well held, and we should not recommend selling “on speo.” We believe the purchase of the Huileries is practically settled. Amongst forthcoming issues is the Egyptian Trust and Investment Co. with a capital ot £200,000. It is not yet on the market, bat as the capital is not large, and some good financial names are mentioned in connection with it, it might easily be made a success in the present prosperous state of Egyptian finanoes. There is a rather better U ne in the mining section generally at the moment Egyptian mining oompanies already show a distinot advanoe on last week's prioes, though as yet business is very limited in the mining market generally. Egypt and Sudan stand at 2 which includes a dividend of 25 per cent and rights to the value of another 75 % in shares of the Sudan Goldfield, Ltd., and the prioe seems low.

div.head: P. & O. COMPANY.
div.p: We are desired to state that the P. & 0. Company's main line steamers to Marseilles regularly leave Port Said at 5 p.m. every Monday after the arrival of the 11 o'clock morning tram from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to oonvey passengers on board.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL

list.item: I. H. Prinoe Adalbert, third soa of the Emperor William, who is a lieutenant on board the German cruiser “Hertha,” is staying at Shephsard’s Hotel, having come on to Cairo from Fort Said.

div.p: The Bail and Countess of IimMissIwsOigh entertained a party at dinner at tfis Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening,tbs guests incl ud mg the Horn J. W. Riddle, the Mis«e Harley, and Lord George Chobnoodeley.
Sir Ernest Cassel and party are axpeoted back in Cairo shortly.
Mr. George Faber, M.P., and Mrs. Faber, who are staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, are
leaving for Europe by the 8.8. “Canopic”.
General and Mrs. Lance have returned to the Tewfik Palace Hotel from up-Kver.

A wound received in Egypt in 1882, two days before tbe battle of Kassassin, has just been the cause of the death of Mr. Rowland Lewis, whioh occurred ten days ago io consequence of inflammation from the wound. Deceased joined the 2nd Life Guards, volun teered for Egypt, and was wounded at Tel-el Kebir. For the last ten years he had been one oi the Assessors of Income Tax in the City ol London._
The German Emperor has conferred th< decoration known as “The Cross of the Orowi of Pruseia” on Mr. A. H. Skynder, architect of Cairo. _

“General” Booth has left London for hii visit to Jerusalem, Australia, and New Zealand travelling viA Dover and Calais to Marseille for Port Said. At the latter place he wil branch off for Jaffa and Jerusalem, returning to Port Said for Colombo, where he is t< arrive on March 28. Thenoe he will prooeed to Australia. «
Dr. Paul Hildebrandt has Jbeen authorisec to follow his profession in Egypt

div.head: NOVELLI AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The stirring adventures that happened tc the great Italian actor Signor NoveUi, as he was on the point of arriving at Alexandria, enhanced the interest of his appearance at the Zizinia Theatre last night, and all Alexandria flocked to hear and see him in AUeiuja. The drama was suited to the occasion as all the characters were garbed in every-day dress, so the complete loss of the troupe’s wardrobe in the “Cairo” was not remarked. NoveUi took the rOle of Alessandro F&ra and was greeted with tremendous applause on making his first appearance. Novelli’s monologue at the dose oi the performance was reoeived with enthusiasm.

div.head: AMATEUR THEATRICALS.
div.p: Enjoyable musical or dramatio entertainments at St Catherine’s College, Alexandria, are by no means of rare oocurrenoe, and these are looked forward to with pleasurable expectancy, by professors, pupils, parents, and friends alike, for some weeks prior to the actual date of performance. We have been privileged to witness many of these entertainments, and to receive, frequently, the weff-known generous hospitality at the hands of the good Brothers. Tuesday’s “slanos rtar&tive et musicals,” which was under the distinguished patronage and presence of M. Pierre Girard, Consul of France, proved no exoeption to the role, and the attractive nature of the programme brought a large crowd of patroffs long before the hour announced for the opening of the doors. The first part of the programme consisted of a musical extravaganza entitled The Happy Man, adapted by Mr. J. Pearoe-Hill, who also introduced several original songs, painted the very effective settings of scenery, and trained the little company of some fifteen youngsters who took part in the prodoo- tion. The performance was, in every way, an unqualified suooesa ; indeed, some ot the young artistes showed suoh histrionic ability as might weU be envied by much older aspirants. As the Rajah, Mr. Nelson Schranz was impressive and acted with ease and dignity. This remark also applies to Mr. G. Garcia, who ably supported the rile of Prinoe Foxi, the grand Vizier. Mr. H. Klat made a very pleasing Prinoe Koko, and in the hands of Mr. P. Esposito, the Court Magioian and Astrologer Ski Hi was a great soooees. Mr. J. Capponi, as Pat Murphy, was quite in his element and kept the large audience in continued. merriment The minor characters were well played by Messrs. P. Perdikides, A. Rathte, V. Paaootto, A. Akaoui, P. Galatis, Z. Simaika, C. Demozantos, S. Stamos, H. Chriatodoulou, and S. Noto. Hie songs and choruses were exceedingly well rendered and brought forth rounds of applause. Tbe staging was admirable, and the costumes gorgeous. Throughout the performance net a point was missed, whksb speaks volumes for the excellence of the college method, seeing that not a single English youth appeared in the piece. Tbe second portion of the programme was devoted to a musical pieoe by Le Roy Villiers entitled Le Moulin du chat qui fume, whioh went with a swing that was highly creditable to all concerned, Messrs. G. Mansour, Z. Mooktar, A. Miohaoa, G, Saunier, 8. Noto, and V, Pasootto being equally successful in their respective rCles. Too much praise cannot be awarded Bro. Jerome for the capable in whioh the various selections were performed by his orchestra, the youthful members of which he has so carefully trained, the Pot Pourri from Il Trouvalors and les Hers de Oeur by Von Suppe being paicularly admired.
